unit: Unit 8 | Inference for Categorical Data: Chi-Square
title: ${\chi}^{2}$: High School Numbers
question_text:
Freshmen, sophomores, juniors, and seniors at a high school were asked to pick a number from $0$ to $9$. A chi-square test was conducted to determine whether the proportion of numbers picked were the same across grade levels.
How many degrees of freedom should the ${\chi}^{2}$ test have?
solution:
The degrees of freedom in a ${ \chi}^{2}$ test of homogeneity is determined by multiplying $(\text{rows}-1)(\text{columns}-1)$ In this case we have $4$ rows (freshmen, sophomores, juniors, and seniors) and $10$ columns (a number $0$ to $9$).

$$\text{Degrees of freedom}=\mathrm{(rows-1)(columns-1)}$$

$$\text{Degrees of freedom}=(4-1)(10-1)= 27$$

Explanation of Distractors Choice 'A' is incorrect. This is not a goodness of fit test. We have several groups($4$ grades) and one categorical variable (which number they pick), thus making this a test of homogeneity. In a goodness of fit test, we have one group and one categorical variable.

Choice 'B' is incorrect. $10$ represents the number of digits from $0$ to $9$.

Choice 'D' is incorrect as this represents $(10-1)\bullet (4)$. The degrees of freedom for the grade level was not subtracted by $1$.

Choice 'E' is incorrect as this represents $(10)\bullet (4)$. One was never subtracted from the digits or the grade level for the degrees of freedom.
